title: Induced current - changed direction and speed

content.description: A conducting rod of length <math alttext="l" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="script">l</mi></math> is pulled to the right with a constant speed. The rod remains in contact at each end with conducting rails connected by a resistor of resistance <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>R</mi></math>. The rod, rails, and resistor are in a uniform magnetic field <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>B</mi></math>, as shown. In Scenario <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn></math>, an external force of magnitude <math alttext="F sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> pulls the rod to the right at constant speed <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and the rate at which energy is dissipated in the resistor is <math alttext="P sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>.
content.question: In Scenario <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, an external force pushes the rod to the left at speed <math alttext="the fraction v sub 0 over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mstyle></math>. Which of the following statements about the magnetic force on the rod is true?

choices.label: The magnetic force on the rod in Scenario <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> is in the same direction and has the same magnitude as the magnetic force on the rod in Scenario <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>.

The magnetic force on the rod in Scenario <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> is in the same direction as the magnetic force on the rod in Scenario <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, but the magnitude of the force is different.

The magnetic force on the rod in Scenario <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> is in the opposite direction of the magnetic force on the rod in Scenario <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, but the magnitude of the force is the same.

The magnetic force on the rod in Scenario <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> is in the opposite direction of the magnetic force on the rod in Scenario <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and the magnitude of the force is different.

content.answer: The magnetic force on the rod in Scenario <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> is in the opposite direction of the magnetic force on the rod in Scenario <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and the magnitude of the force is different.
